Audio Connectors

3.5mm, 6.35mm, XLR, RCA, and optical audio connectors.

4 connector types documented

3.5mm

3.5mm Audio Jack (1/8 inch)

IEC 60603-11

Max Speed

0 Mbps

Connector

4 pins, 3.5×3.5mm

Common Uses

Headphones Earbuds Smartphones (older models) +6 more

⚠️ TRS (3 conductors) and TRRS (4 conductors) look nearly identical but aren't fully compatible

The 3.5mm jack has been the universal audio connector for decades, but is being phased out of smartphones in favor of USB-C or wireless. The connector originated from 19th century telephone switchboards (the 6.35mm version) and was miniaturized for transistor radios in the 1950s. Despite being 'obsolete' it remains ubiquitous due to simplicity and universal compatibility.

6.35mm

6.35mm Audio Jack (1/4 inch)

IEC 60603-11

Max Speed

0 Mbps

Connector

3 pins, 6.35×6.35mm

Common Uses

Electric guitars and basses Guitar amplifiers Audio interfaces +6 more

⚠️ TS and TRS look almost identical but serve different purposes - TS for instruments, TRS for balanced or stereo

The 6.35mm jack dates back to 1878 telephone switchboards, making it one of the oldest electrical connectors still in common use. Its durability and simplicity have kept it standard in professional audio and musical instruments. While consumer electronics moved to 3.5mm, the 1/4" connector remains dominant in professional audio where its larger size allows for more robust connections.

RCA

RCA Connector

None (de facto standard)

Max Speed

3.072 Mbps

Connector

1 pins, 8×8mm

Common Uses

Home theater receivers DVD/Blu-ray players Turntables +6 more

⚠️ Audio RCA cables and video RCA cables may look identical but video cables need 75Ω impedance

RCA connectors were introduced by the Radio Corporation of America in the 1930s for internal phonograph connections. They became the consumer A/V standard through the 20th century. While being replaced by HDMI and digital connections, RCA remains common on audio equipment, especially subwoofers, turntables, and home theater receivers. The connector's simplicity is both its strength and weakness - easy to use but unbalanced and prone to interference.

XLR

XLR Connector

IEC 61076-2-103

Max Speed

0.25 Mbps

Connector

3 pins, 19×19mm

Common Uses

Professional microphones Audio interfaces Mixing consoles +5 more

⚠️ XLR cables and DMX cables use the same connector but have different impedance - don't mix them for long runs

XLR was invented by James H. Cannon (hence 'Cannon connector') and the name comes from the X series with a Latch and Rubber compound. It became the professional audio standard due to its balanced design (which rejects interference), locking mechanism, and durability. The gendered connector design (male output, female input) allows daisy-chaining without adapter cables.

About Audio Connectors

Audio connectors range from consumer headphone jacks to professional studio equipment. The physical connector often indicates the intended use case and signal type.

Consumer Audio

  • 3.5mm TRS - Headphones, aux cables
  • RCA - Home audio, component video
  • Optical (TOSLINK) - Digital audio

Professional Audio

  • XLR - Balanced, interference-resistant
  • 6.35mm (1/4") - Instruments, studio
  • Speakon - High-power speaker cables
